content: The Act may be cited as the "Crowdsourcing and Citizen Science Act of 2015". The America COMPETES Reauthorization Act of 2010 has allowed Federal agencies to use incentive prizes and challenges, resulting in benefits such as paying only for success, setting ambitious goals, involving a broader group of people, and bringing diverse perspectives to problem-solving. The America COMPETES Reauthorization Act of 2010 has enabled Federal agencies to use incentive prizes and challenges, allowing them to set ambitious goals, involve a broader group of people, bring diverse perspectives to problem-solving, and increase cost-effectiveness. Granting agencies direct authority to use crowdsourcing and citizen science will remove ambiguity about their ability to do so. The America COMPETES Reauthorization Act of 2010 has enabled Federal agencies to use incentive prizes and challenges to set ambitious goals, involve a broader group of people, bring diverse perspectives to problem-solving, and increase cost-effectiveness. Granting agencies direct authority to use crowdsourcing and citizen science will remove ambiguity and stimulate broader public participation in the innovation process. Crowdsourcing projects offer unique benefits such as improving government service delivery with lower resource investments and connecting citizens to Federal missions. The benefits of crowdsourcing projects include improving government service delivery with lower resource investments, connecting citizens to Federal missions, and acquiring data at a greater geographic extent and density. Citizen science promotes open government, volunteerism, and enables citizens to gather, analyze, and share data to address community concerns. It also accelerates scientific research. Citizen science accelerates scientific research, promotes open government, volunteerism, and enables citizens to address community concerns by gathering, analyzing, and sharing data. It also improves science literacy and enhances skills in STEM fields, increasing American competitiveness. Citizen science accelerates scientific research, promotes open government, volunteerism, and enables citizens to address community concerns by gathering, analyzing, and sharing data. It also improves science literacy, enhances skills in STEM fields, increases American competitiveness, furthers science diplomacy, and builds trust and understanding between citizens and scientists. Participants in crowdsourcing and citizen science contribute to these efforts. Federal agencies should consider providing meaningful incentives to engage and retain participants in crowdsourcing and citizen science projects, including receiving attribution for their contributions. Federal agencies should consider providing incentives for participants in crowdsourcing and citizen science projects, such as receiving attribution, learning new skills, connecting with others, and contributing to solving meaningful problems. Participants in crowdsourcing and citizen science projects are motivated by learning new skills, connecting with others, and contributing to solving meaningful problems for the benefit of society. SEC. 3. CROWDSOURCING AND CITIZEN SCIENCE. Citizen science involves open collaboration where individuals or organizations participate in various scientific processes, including formulating research questions, designing projects, conducting experiments, collecting and analyzing data, interpreting results, developing technologies, making discoveries, and solving problems. Citizen science involves open collaboration in scientific processes such as project design, conducting experiments, data collection and analysis, result interpretation, technology development, discoveries, and problem-solving. Crowdsourcing is a method to obtain services, ideas, or content from a group, especially online. The Director refers to the Director of the organization. The term "crowdsourcing" is defined as a method to obtain services, ideas, or content from a group, especially online. The term "Director" refers to the Director of the Office of Science and Technology Policy. The term "Federal agency" includes any Executive agency as defined in section 105 of title 5, United States Code. The Office of Science and Technology Policy defines "Federal agency" as any Executive agency or military department, excluding legislative branch agencies. A "participant" is an individual or entity that volunteers consent. The term "related entity" refers to Federal Government contractors, subcontractors, suppliers, users, customers, and cooperating parties. The head of each Federal agency or multiple agencies working together may authorize individuals or entities to participate as volunteers in crowdsourcing or citizen science projects. A "related entity" includes Federal Government contractors, subcontractors, suppliers, users, customers, cooperating parties, grantees, investigators, fellows, or detailees of a Federal agency. The head of each Federal agency or multiple agencies working together may utilize crowdsourcing and citizen science approaches with volunteers, including individuals or entities like contractors, subcontractors, suppliers, users, customers, cooperating parties, grantees, investigators, fellows, or detailees of a Federal agency. The head of a Federal agency can accept voluntary services from participants involved in crowdsourcing or citizen science projects authorized by the agency. Federal agencies can accept voluntary services from participants in crowdsourcing or citizen science projects authorized by the Office of Personnel Management, as long as the services are unpaid and do not displace any federal employees. Federal agencies engaged in crowdsourcing or citizen science projects must promote and encourage broad participation of consenting participants. Each agency must ensure that participants are not financially compensated, and their involvement will not displace any federal employees. Additionally, agencies must obtain consent, registration, and define terms of use for the projects. Each Federal agency conducting crowdsourcing or citizen science projects must promote and encourage broad participation of consenting participants. Agencies have the authority to determine the level of consent, registration, or acknowledgment of terms of use required from participants on a project-by-project basis. Federal agencies conducting crowdsourcing or citizen science projects must disclose key terms such as privacy, intellectual property, data ownership, compensation, and program details to participants in a clear and reasonable manner. When conducting crowdsourcing or citizen science projects, Federal agencies must disclose key terms such as privacy, intellectual property, data ownership, compensation, and program details to participants in a clear and reasonable manner, and may obtain consent electronically or in written form. Federal agencies can obtain consent electronically or in written form from participants for crowdsourcing or citizen science projects. Projects involving human subjects must adhere to regulations, and agencies should strive to make data available while maintaining security and privacy protections. Federal agencies conducting crowdsourcing or citizen science projects involving human subjects must comply with regulations for research. Data collected should be made available to the public in machine-readable formats, while maintaining security and privacy protections. Participants must be informed of how the data will be used during the consent process. Federal agencies conducting crowdsourcing or citizen science projects must make data collected available to the public in machine-readable formats. Participants must be informed of the expected uses of the data, ownership retention by the agency, availability of data for public use, and their authorization to publish the data. Federal agencies conducting crowdsourcing or citizen science projects must make data collected available to the public in machine-readable formats. They should also inform participants about data ownership, availability for public use, and authorization to publish the data. Additionally, agencies should strive to make technologies and applications developed through these projects accessible to the public. Federal agencies conducting crowdsourcing or citizen science projects must make technologies, applications, code, and derivations of intellectual property developed through these projects open and available to the public. Participants in these projects must agree to assume all associated risks and waive claims against the Federal Government. Participants in crowdsourcing or citizen science projects must agree to assume all risks and waive claims against the Federal Government, except for claims based on willful misconduct. Participants in citizen science projects must waive all claims against the Federal Government, except for those based on willful misconduct. Federal agencies coordinating such projects must ensure participants adhere to scientific integrity and ethics policies. Federal agencies coordinating citizen science projects must ensure participants adhere to scientific integrity and ethics policies. They may enter into partnerships with private sector entities for administrative duties. Federal agencies engaged in crowdsourcing or citizen science activities can partner with private sector entities or government agencies to share administrative duties. Funding for these activities can come from appropriated funds by Congress. In carrying out crowdsourcing and citizen science activities, Federal agencies can use funds appropriated by Congress or accept funds from other Federal agencies, private sector entities, or private institutions of higher education. Federal agencies conducting crowdsourcing and citizen science activities can use funds from Congress or accept funds from other Federal agencies, private sector entities, or government agencies without giving special consideration in return. Federal agencies conducting crowdsourcing and citizen science activities can use funds from Congress or accept funds from other Federal agencies, private sector entities, or government agencies without giving special consideration in return. The General Services Administration, in coordination with the Director, will develop products and services to facilitate the use of such funds within 180 days of the Act's enactment. The General Services Administration will develop products and services to facilitate crowdsourcing and citizen science activities within 180 days of the Act's enactment. The General Services Administration will develop products and services to facilitate crowdsourcing and citizen science activities. Federal agencies are encouraged to consult guidance provided by the Director for carrying out these activities to further the policy objectives of the Federal Government. A report is required to be submitted every 2 years after the enactment of the Act. The Federal Government encourages Federal agencies engaged in crowdsourcing or citizen science to consult guidance provided by the Director. A report on these activities must be submitted every 2 years. The Director shall report on crowdsourcing and citizen science projects conducted by Federal agencies every 2 years, as required by the Stevenson-Wydler Technology Innovation Act of 1980. The Director shall report on crowdsourcing and citizen science projects conducted by Federal agencies every 2 years, as required by the Stevenson-Wydler Technology Innovation Act of 1980. The report shall include a summary of each project, participation rates, submission levels, consents, and other relevant statistics. The Director's report on crowdsourcing and citizen science projects by Federal agencies every 2 years includes goals, participation rates, resources used, and activities undertaken in each project. The Director's report on crowdsourcing and citizen science projects by Federal agencies every 2 years includes details on resources used, activities undertaken, and allocation of obligations and expenditures among agency accounts. The Director's report on crowdsourcing and citizen science projects by Federal agencies every 2 years includes details on resources used, activities undertaken, allocation of obligations and expenditures among agency accounts, ways projects advanced agency mission, and project results. The Director's report on crowdsourcing and citizen science projects by Federal agencies every 2 years includes details on resources used, activities undertaken, allocation of obligations and expenditures among agency accounts, ways projects advanced agency mission, project results, methods for data quality assurance, data availability, and any savings or costs incurred by the Federal Government. The Director's report on crowdsourcing and citizen science projects by Federal agencies every 2 years includes details on resources used, activities undertaken, allocation of obligations and expenditures among agency accounts, ways projects advanced agency mission, project results, data quality assurance methods, data availability, savings or costs incurred by the Federal Government, and main challenges faced by Federal agencies. The report on crowdsourcing and citizen science projects by Federal agencies every 2 years includes details on resources used, activities undertaken, challenges faced, steps taken to address challenges, and recommendations for future action. The report on crowdsourcing and citizen science projects by Federal agencies every 2 years includes details on resources used, activities undertaken, challenges faced, steps taken to address challenges, recommendations for future action, summary of methods used, interagency partnerships, and any other relevant information. The report on crowdsourcing and citizen science projects by Federal agencies every 2 years includes details on resources used, activities undertaken, challenges faced, steps taken to address challenges, recommendations for future action, summary of methods used, interagency partnerships, and any other relevant information. Additionally, the Director may include a summary of the use of crowdsourcing and citizen science methods by all Federal agencies, interagency and multi-sector partnerships, and any other relevant information. Nothing in this section may affect the authority to conduct crowdsourcing and citizen science authorized by other laws or displace Federal Government resources allocated to agencies using crowdsourcing or citizen science. Savings Provisions: This section does not affect the authority to conduct crowdsourcing and citizen science authorized by other laws or displace Federal Government resources allocated to agencies using crowdsourcing or citizen science.
